Award.AbstractNarration:
John D'Angelo will continue his study of Hermitian forms and their applications to several complex variables and CR geometry. This work lies at the foundation of a developing area in mathematics, complexity theory in CR Geometry, while also enabling connections to other branches of mathematics. The starting point concerns CR mappings between spheres and hyperquadrics; it goes on to study various notions of complexity for CR mappings, the signature pair of a Hermitian symmetric function, and representation theory for finite unitary groups. Applications include Hermitian analogues of Hilbert's 17-th problem, revolving around new matrix positivity conditions for Hermitian polynomials on algebraic sets. This work is closely related to a non-linear form of the Cauchy-Schwartz inequality and to the notion of Hermitian nullity of a set with respect to a real ideal. These results will lead to striking links between the geometry of a real hypersurface in complex Euclidean space and basic questions in algebra.


Mapping theorems in one complex dimension have long played a central role in mathematics, physics, and engineering. The proposed work can be regarded as developing the fundamental ideas in higher dimensions, where the situation becomes much more subtle and new phenomena arise. The resulting work leads to a promising and unusual combination of analysis, geometry, and algebra. In 1900 the mathematician David Hilbert set out a list of 23 problems. These problems continue to drive much of current day mathematical research. The famous 17th problem was solved in the 1920s. D'Angelo's work has led to Hermitian analogues of this problem, where new difficulties appear and connections to many areas of mathematics arise. D'Angelo will continue to mentor young mathematicians (including graduate students) in these topics and to organize and attend conferences. He will also continue teaching a new complex analysis course he has developed for Honors freshmen.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's work on Hermitian Forms and CR Geometry aims to connect classical mathematics with recent developments.  One of the principal achievements of this grant was the publication of the book "Hermitian Analysis: From Fourier Series to Cauchy-Riemann Geometry". This book starts with classical mathematics, used extensively in Engineering and Physics, and shows how it leads to research questions in several complex variables and CR Geometry.

 

The unit circle in the complex plane played a crucial role in Fourier analysis, partial differential equations, mathematical physics, and electrical engineering. The PI has worked extensively on extending these ideas to higher dimensions by way of his work on CR mappings between unit spheres in different dimensions. It turns out that one must study Hermitian forms and positivity conditions for them. The PI invented a concept he calls "orthogonal homogenization" in order to classify CR mappings between spheres. This concept seems to be required for understanding many of the basics issues. It surprised the PI when this concept led to a variational problem for the complex Monge-Ampere equation, thereby providing a new inequality on volumes of holomorphic images. This result is a higher dimensional analogue of an elementary idea. Of all smooth closed curves in the plane with a given perimeter, the circle encloses the most area. The PI's result considers polynomial images of the unit sphere inside higher dimensional unit spheres, and gives the maximum volume in terms of the dimension and the degree. This maximum volume is achieved by maps that generalize raising a complex number to a positive integer power.  Raising a complex number to the n-th power takes the circle to itself but covers it n times. This transformation plays a crucial role in orthonormal expansions such as Fourier series. The elegance of the ideas suggests that future applications are possible.

Related work (mapping spheres to spheres with group invariance) has led also to connections with various other parts of mathematics, including combinatorics and number theory.  The overall feeling is that the research in this grant connects with topics throughout mathematics in an artistic way, and hence is likely to lead to additional applications.
